Additive degeneration and the Steenrod algebra

Feb 14, 2019

Let denote the additive formal group over , so that . The coproduct sends to . Let us attempt to understand automorphisms of : this is the data of an such that . Since we’re in characteristic , this forces ; in particular, the space of such power series is given by (where ). The automorphism group is also a group, under composition, and we can use this to work out the coproduct on . Suppose is another such automorphism; then

It follows that the coproduct sends to . This is precisely the characterization of the Steenrod algebra, so we conclude that the automorphism group of the additive formal group over is represented by of the dual Steenrod algebra. In particular, quasicoherent sheaves over are the same as Steenrod comodules, i.e., -vector spaces along with an action of . If denotes the universal formal group over (which is exactly the additive formal group over along with the action of its automorphism group), then the above formulae make it clear that is precisely the cohomology ring along with its Steenrod action.

We know that there are interesting quotient Hopf algebras of the dual Steenrod algebra, so it is natural to ask if this is somehow reflected in algebraic geometry.

Let denote the moduli stack of possibly singular quadratic curves, defined by equations modulo translations . Suppose that the quadratic curve parametrized by this equation is smooth, so is a unit. Let and be roots of ; then, there is a unique group structure on with as the unit, which sends to . This makes isomorphic to the multiplicative group. If is not a unit (i.e., is singular), then the curve has additive degeneration, and we find that there’s a map . (In fact, is the stack associated to the connective spectrum (in the sense of this document).) This morphism is representable.

In particular, if denotes the projectivization of the singular quadratic over , then there is a closed immersion . The group scheme is affine, and so if we write , then is a quotient Hopf algebra of . The most natural candidate (given that this is motivated by ) is — but this is false! So: can we see this algebro-geometrically? (Note that .) Since everything is so explicit, and is so simple, this is easy:

These are automorphisms of the affine algebraic curve , but only the latter automorphism extends to one of the projectivization. And indeed, . Suppose that classifies this singular quadratic curve (where now denotes the moduli of quadratic curves over -local rings); then, . Since is the stack associated to the Eilenberg-Maclane spectrum , so we might expect that is the stack (over ) associated to the -algebra . This stack is affine, and is given by ; in particular, if is the stack (scheme) associated to , we would find that ; but this is false, since . (This final claim is equivalent to the statement that .) It is interesting, though, that sits inside the automorphism group scheme of the affine cuspidal quadratic.

We note the following interesting result, due to Bhattacharya, Egger, and Mahowald: there is a type spectrum such that ; in other words, as comodules over the dual Steenrod algebra. This amounts to the statement that there is a coherent sheaf over supported away from (which is where the smooth locus of lands under the morphism ) such that .

We can attempt to run the same exercise for the moduli of cubic curves. In this case, it is known that is the stack associated to . At the prime , we know that (which is equivalent to the statement that ). Now, if denotes the projectivization of the singular curve over , then (as is worked out in Lemma 3.5 here). At the prime , something weird happens: there is an isomorphism , where is dual to the subalgebra of generated by and , and is a degree element with

I don’t know where this comes from, because I haven’t worked out the automorphisms of the cuspidal cubic over , but I expect that this mysterious element will be found in its automorphism group.

In any case, this raises a few interesting questions. One important question which comes up often is how one can take connective covers of periodic -rings. Namely, suppose is an -ring arising as the global sections of an even-periodic refinement of a flat and affine map from a Noetherian and separated Deligne-Mumford stack, so that is periodic with some even period. (The periodicity claim is not too hard to prove; here’s a sketch. There is some periodicity generator in , and we would like to prove that some power of survives the descent spectral sequence. Since the map is affine, and , we conclude that is an affine scheme; in particular, the -page (and hence all pages) of the spectral sequence is torsion, so by the Leibniz rule, for each , there is some such that . Now, the descent spectral sequence agrees with the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for , e.g., by Theorem 4 of this document, so since is -local for some by Noetherianness of , we conclude that the descent spectral sequence generates at some finite page ; in this case, survives the descent spectral sequence, and is therefore a periodicity generator for .) An example of such an is . However, taking the connective cover of is a bad idea: the -localization of will not be equivalent to ! Instead, one extends the moduli problem to the cusp, and this gives the non-periodic -ring . The “junk” which is Grothendieck-Serre-Anderson dual to the positive degree elements is concentrated entirely in negative degrees, so one isn’t left with any negative-dimensional “ghosts” if we take the connective cover; and indeed, by defining , one obtains a very nice connective -spectrum.

The same story could, of course, be told for , but it’s not nearly as interesting because one doesn’t have to extend over the cusp. In both cases, though, we find that if (which could now denote or ) has some kind of Serre duality, then taking the connective cover of will yield a well-behaved spectrum if the product of negative-dimensional elements of with positive-dimensional elements never yields a nontrivial element of nonnegative dimension (not true for but true for ). On the level of algebra, the stack associated to would be some extension of the moduli problem associated to that takes additive degeneration into account (somewhat more precisely, this stack would add a point to which is in the closure of any point in ). It’s kinda impossible to devise a general procedure to do so for a general algebraically defined stack , and this corresponds topologically to the fact that it’s hard to take connective covers of -local -rings “in the right way”. If this is possible for , though, then the above discussion shows that it is reasonable (and I apologize for getting philosophical) to try to understand (which is equivalent to understanding ) by studying automorphisms of .
